message.content: We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The cleavage of procollagen C- and N-terminals occurs extracellularly, while glycosylation of pro-α chains, triple-helix formation, and translation of pro-α chains all occur intracellularly.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. Procollagen is cleaved into its C- and N-terminals extracellularly to form tropocollagen, which then undergoes triple-helix formation before being stabilized by covalent crosslinks. Glycosylation of pro-α chains occurs in the rough endoplasmic reticulum, and translation of pro-α chains occurs in the cytoplasm.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. Option B, cleavage of procollagen C- and N-terminals, occurs extracellularly, specifically outside the cell after secretion. Glycosylation of pro-α chains occurs in the Golgi, triple-helix formation occurs in the endoplasmic reticulum, and translation of pro-α chains occurs in the cytoplasm.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. Choice B is correct because procollagen is cleaved into collagen molecules via enzyme activity once it is in the extracellular space. Choices A, C, and D all occur intracellularly before the procollagen molecule is secreted.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The cleavage of procollagen C- and N-terminals occurs extracellularly, specifically outside of the cell in the extracellular matrix. Glycosylation of pro-α chains occurs in the endoplasmic reticulum and Golgi apparatus, triple-helix formation occurs inside the endoplasmic reticulum, and translation of pro-α chains occurs in the cytoplasm.

We refer to a medical article on the process of collagen synthesis. The cleavage of procollagen C- and N-terminals occurs extracellularly, while glycosylation of pro-α chains occurs in the endoplasmic reticulum and Golgi apparatus, triple-helix formation occurs intracellularly, and translation of pro-α chains occurs on ribosomes in the cytoplasm.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The question specifically asks for the step in collagen synthesis that occurs extracellularly. The only option that fits this description is (B): the cleavage of procollagen C- and N-terminals, which occurs outside of the cell to form mature collagen. Glycosylation of pro-α chains, triple-helix formation, and translation of pro-α chains all occur inside the cell before the collagen is secreted.

We refer to our understanding of collagen synthesis. Procollagen chains undergo glycosylation in the rough endoplasmic reticulum, triple-helix formation in the Golgi apparatus, and translation in the cytoplasm. The extracellular step in collagen synthesis involves cleavage of the procollagen C- and N-terminals to form mature collagen.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. During collagen synthesis, glycosylation of pro-α chains occurs in the rough endoplasmic reticulum, triple-helix formation occurs in the Golgi apparatus, and translation of pro-α chains occurs in the cytoplasm. Cleavage of procollagen C- and N-terminals occurs extracellularly to form mature collagen fibrils.
We refer to Wikipedia articles on collagen synthesis for help. The cleavage of procollagen C- and N-terminals occurs extracellularly, while the other options occur intracellularly.
